clusterList.phrase: our findings along with those from the wisconsin cohort remove any reasonable doubt that sleep apnea is a fatal disease
when you stop breathing in your sleep you don't know it it doesn't typically wake you up
sleep-disordered breathing and mortality eighteen-year follow-up of the wisconsin sleep cohort
when you stop breathing in your sleep you don t know it it doesn t typically wake you up
this is the first study to demonstrate an independent association between all-cause mortality and sleep apnea in a community-based study

the size of the increased mortality risk was surprisingly large in our particular study a six-fold increase means that having significant sleep apnea at age 40 gives you about the same mortality risk as somebody aged 57 who doesn't have sleep apnea
people who have or suspect that they have sleep apnea should consult their physicians about diagnosis and treatment options
sleep apnea as an independent risk factor for all-cause mortality the busselton health study

we found that both men and women with sleep apnea in the general population not patients mostly undiagnosed and untreated had poorer survival compared with persons without sleep apnea given equal bmi age and sex
our findings suggest but cannot prove that people diagnosed with sleep apnea should be treated and if cpap is the prescribed treatment regular use may prevent premature death
